DR. AMES NEW CHAIRMAN
OF NATIONAL AERONAUTIC COMMITTEE
DeAn to Go to Europe This Summer
Upon Return of President
Goodnow

Dr. Joseph S. Ames, Dean of the
College Faculty and acting president
of the University, was signally honored recently by being elected chairman of the National Advisory
Committee for Aeronautics. He
succeeds Dr. Charles D. Walcott
who recently died.
The National Advisory Committee is composed of prominent military, naval, and technical men, who
rank high in aeronautical circles in
this country. The Board has active
charge of all technical work and research undertaken by the United
States government in aeronautics.
Dr. Ames has been a member of
the Committee since its inception in
1916, being appointed by President
Wilson shortly before this country
entered the Great War. He served
during hostilities as a "dollar-a-day
man," and had a great deal to do
with the technical experiments carried on by the government in aviation. He has been chairman of the
executive body of the Committe for
the past four years.
Member Since 1916

Dr. Ames will now have personal
supervision of all technical work
done for the Government in this
field. Under his direction work will
be carried on in eight large aeronautical laboratories, situated at Langley Field, Va. These laboratories
are the largest and best equipped of
their kind in the world.
Headquarters in Washington

The headquarters of the Committee is in Washington, where offices
are maintained in the Navy Building. Congress has created a budget
of $520,000 to be used in areonautics, and Dr. Ames will control and
direct all expenditures of the Committee.
It was also announced that the
Dean will make a trip to Europe this
summer, leaving immediately upon
the return of President Goodnow,
who sailed for England Saturday.

MR. KEYES' RESIGNATION
The resignation of Norman Chase Keyes as graduate manager
of athletics is cause for comment. We cannot help but welcome
Mr.
the action, because we feel that whatever anyone's opinion of

the treasurer's office.
Rumor has it that no one will be appointed to fill the position
next year, assuming of course, the foregone conclusion of the acceptance of the resignation by the Athletic Council. The making
of schedules can easily be carried out by undergraduate managers
with the advice of the coaches. The financial details of the athletic association could readily be handled by the treasurer of. the
association in conjunction with the treasurer of the University.
Athletic publicity can be arranged by the Director of Athletics.
All of the duties that have fallen to the graduate manager can,
as has been shown, be subdivided among other individuals, allowing the salary of the graduate manager to be allocated to the purchasing of additional athletic equipment. We believe that everyone concerned will benefit by Mr. Keyes' resignation.

TH E APPOINTMENT OF DR. MILES
The appointment of Dr. L. Wardlaw Miles to the English
faculty will be viewed with a good deal of satisfaction by those
who know Dr. Miles either personally or through his writings
and lectures. He seems to be a man who combines a thorough
knowledge and ardent love of his subject with a sympathetic
understanding of those whom he is teaching. His work at the Gilman Country School was of the highest order and has marked him
as being peculiarly fitted for the position he will fill at this University next year.

WELCOME, NAVY
If one can be welcomed with the wish that he goes home sad
and down-hearted, we welcome Navy. Hopkins-Navy lacrosse
games have been classics of the sport for the past three or fur
years, and this year promises to climax a brilliant series of contests. That we will beat Navy, the NEWS-LETTER feels is more
than a possibility: we believe that the team is equal to the task.
At any rate, we welcome the Navy most heartily.

JUST A STAGE KISS
By EVANS RODGERS
entitled to a little recreation !" Oscar
a
all,
man's
it
"Damn
growled. Oscar had been arguing with Agatha, his wife. Of
course, it was on the same, age-old subject—would she never let
him alone in his pet avocation! Amateur theatricals were not, as
she continually told him, merely a beautiful opportunity for conceited asses to strut their vanity at the unwilling expense of their
friends' time. His hobby was artistic in a way. And then too,
the other fellows had their recreations: golf, tennis, insipid bridge,
and perfectly worthless canceled stamps! By God, he'd have his!
"Oscar !" came a voice from across the hall. It was spoken
in a tone suggestive of the individual he had just sworn by, but
Oscar was determined. "What!" he bellowed back. "Come here!"
and he stuck to his
s
Oscar wilted visibly, but the door was .hut
guns. "You come here," he ventured, but it was softer enough
for her to know. Agatha decided to cry: that was much the
quickest way. Oscar was always nice to her when she cried,
although she never quite knew why—she thought it disgusting.
So she opened the door very slowly and entered martyr-like, instead of blustering in like the tigress she was.
"Oscar," she said with a timely sob, "don't you really feel
anything when you kiss that awful leading lady ?" "Don't be asinine!" Evidently Oscar was madder than usual. "I feel her lips
on mine, of course." "But, dear, I mean it doesn't mean anything
at all?"
By jacks, Agatha was pretty. And here she was crying—the
dear! He slipped his arm around her; and Agatha quickly got her
head on his chest, her eyes and mouth out of sight. "Darling," he
went on softly, pitching his voice down two tones to where Mr.
Gegotensky had told him his most seducing sounds were, "a moment before I kiss her I tear up a letter, a moment after I light a
cigarette. All three of these are merely stage business—that's all.
Each one is as important as the other two, and all three most pleasant when I do them well. (Pretty nicely said, Oscar thought,
some day he'd have to write something too.) But can't you understand?" "And it doesn't mean a thing ?" "Not a thing!" he answered, and he knew he was taking the right attitude, the professional attitude.

Well, the play was over at last. Oscar sighed a little. Now
he'd have to get down to business, he'd had his fun and now to
work. Of course, it had been fun. His friends were all very kind
after his performance, and although he would surely discount some
of the more obvious flattery, these people knew what they were
talking about all right. And he wasn't such a fool as to call himself conceited when he knew he had done a good thing. No, no,
that type was the worst of all—inferiority complexes, afraid to be
frank about their good qualities. And then he had had some quite
sensible adverse criticism too. For instance, the fellow who said
his leading lady hadn't given him all the reactions she might have,
and the one who saw immediately that the play itself had held back
so many of his most attractive little touches.
But now that was all over. Yes, yes, he'd rave to get back to
the grind now, and make up for some of those long hours of rehearsing. Besides, it would please Agatha so if he quit for a while.
Yes, he'd have to tell the Spielshoppers that he simply couldn't
keep his promise about that new play of theirs. He had told them
that as soon as this other one was over, he'd come to them, but a
man couldn't waste all his time on his recreation! The world was
too much with him for that! They had been rehearsing two weeks
without him with an understudy, but—well, let the other fellow
have a shot at a part. Sure, that was it. The Spielshoppers needed
some young blood anyway. And then, too, he was very busy, very
busy. Yes, there was the answer; he'd go right over and let them
beg all they pleased; he just wouldn't do it. And he'd come back
to Agatha immediately.
The stage manager of the Spielshoppers met him at the door
of the little theater. In a moment they were inside. "Here you
are, Oscar," he was saying proudly, "your leading lady, Miss
Keener." It didn't take Oscar a second to grasp the whole situation. The large brown eyes, the perfect little nose, the luscious
mouth, the skin as clear as crystal and as smooth as velvet.
"You know, I just couldn't wait to get over to this play of
yours!" Oscar announced confidentially. "Damn glad that other
thing is over---it was such a farce! How have you managed with
the understudy? Pretty bad, eh? . . . No? What? Oh!.
Well, let's get started by all means!"
No, no, Agatha, not a thing, not a thing!

The young College battled against
terrific odds, but its plans were well
ordered for a larger growth. The
spirit of its founders was transmitted
to the successors and today the College looks with just pride upon its
traditional spirit as well as upon its
achievements. During the Civil
War Waterville College felt the call
to arms so keenly that only fifty
students were left in residence there.
The name was again changed
after the war to Colby in honor of
Gardiner Colby, who left the handsome endowment of $50,000.
Shortly after this another, quite a
momentous, change took place;
Colby became coeducational. The
College was truly a pioneer in the

coed movement.
This college is not widely known.
That is to say that it has none of
the fame of Harvard, Yale, Princeton, or Johns Hopkins and it does
not compare with them in size.
Nevertheless it is the subject of a
very interesting history. The life
of the school has contirrued at times
thru difficulty, but it has continued
to live and its fair name is supported
by no small retinue of distinguished
persons.
Colby bases its claim to fame
upon the successes of its graduates.
Looking over • the account of this
history one cannot but reflect upon
the progress of Johns Hopkins University.
Certainly compared to many other
colleges this university is very
young. However, in spite of the
fact that it has just celebrated its
fiftieth birthday, its short life has
been luminated by a veritable
galaxy of famous names. The
Medical School alone has made a
remarkably noteworthy contribution
to medical science. In addition
there is scarcely a field in which
Johns Hopkins has not been represented by an exceptional student.

and relays in this important district. Here he will be found today, acting as intermediary between the sales force on the one
hand and the engineering and
factory departments on the other.
He backs up the salesmen with
a highly specialized knowledge.
He advises with the engineers
and with the factory in the design
and manufacture of apparatus
that is best suited to commercial
requirements.
His own pioneering spirit has

still found field for play, so that
this year he demonstrated to the
A. I. E. E. the first advance in
the method of calibrating watthour meters in thirty years.
Some 16,000,000 tests of watthour meters are made in this
country annually. They cost
about 20C apiece. Sparkes has
devised a practicable method that
chops more than so% off this
bill—a tidy saving. It eliminates
the human element; it gives
greatly improved accuracy.
Thus his first ten years at
Westinghouse—and not unlike
that of other college men who
bring with them,when they come
here, energy, imagination, and
the groundwork upon which to
build superlative engineering
proficiency.

Westinghouse

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS LETTER MAY 6, 1927

4

J. H. FURST CO.
Printers of
PHILOLOGICAL & SCIENTIFIC
PUBLICATIONS
23 S. Hanover St., Baltimore
Blood and something akin to thunder, heightened by bold
stage settings of red and black, provided novel entertainment at
the Playshop Theater Monday night in the forni of a fiery Spanish
melodrama.
The play is "The Great Galeoto," by Jose Echagaray, considered the best work of the playwright. It represents another addition to the list of national dramas presented by the Hopkins little
theater group this season.
Repeated curtain calls at the end of each act and almost unanimous applause during the progress of the play gave evidence of
the sympathetic reception accorded the efforts of the Playshoppers
by the most demonstrative audience of the year. •
It was the spirit and ability of the principals in the cast that
carried off successfully what was undoubtedly a very difficult and,
at times, bloody task. For the play itself is of that highly emotional type which fairly boils with the struggle of the fiercer passions and which employs diction that is sometimes too rhetorical
to be convincing. It takes good acting, in this cynical age, to keep
such a play from being laughed at.
The play was much improved, in the modern sense, according to the Play-shop management, by judicious cutting and revising of long soliloquies and asides, "naturalizing the florid artificial
diction and subduing to some slight extent the interpretation."
Jealousy, inflamed by false gossip, is the driving force of the
drama. Don Julian, a wealthy elderly Spanish gentleman, ot upright character, is happily married to a pretty young girl of twenty,
who loves him deeply. Living with them is an impulsive young
man whom Don Julian has befriended. People begin to talk maliciously of the really blameless relations between the two young
people. This gossip, broadcast by chronic scandal-mongers, among
whom is Don Julian's brother, comes finally to the ears of the husband and the insidious poison, working in him, results in bloodshed
and tragedy.
Elise Cohen, as Julian's wife carries off this very exacting
role without any awkwardness at all. Although she is not quite
equal to several of the boiling points of emotion in the play,
she displays throughout a grace and poise and variety of expression that at once attract and hold attention.
Evans Rodgers, of Barnstormers fame, in the part of the
fiery young Spaniard, has appearance against him. He has to
act against the handicap of not looking like a poet-lover-swordsman of the romantic Ramon Navarro type which the part seems
to call for. This, of course, is purely a matter of nationality or
make-up, for Rodgers certainly gets all the necessary steam behind.
the role and he really acts—there are no mistaking the particular
shades of emotion he wants to get across.
R. K.

DR. AMES NEW CHAIRMAN
OF NATIONAL AERONAUTIC COMMITTEE
DeAn to Go to Europe This Summer
Upon Return of President
Goodnow

Dr. Joseph S. Ames, Dean of the
College Faculty and acting president
of the University, was signally honored recently by being elected chairman of the National Advisory
Committee for Aeronautics. He
succeeds Dr. Charles D. Walcott
who recently died.
The National Advisory Committee is composed of prominent military, naval, and technical men, who
rank high in aeronautical circles in
this country. The Board has active
charge of all technical work and research undertaken by the United
States government in aeronautics.
Dr. Ames has been a member of
the Committee since its inception in
1916, being appointed by President
Wilson shortly before this country
entered the Great War. He served
during hostilities as a "dollar-a-day
man," and had a great deal to do
with the technical experiments carried on by the government in aviation. He has been chairman of the
executive body of the Committe for
the past four years.
Member Since 1916

Dr. Ames will now have personal
supervision of all technical work
done for the Government in this
field. Under his direction work will
be carried on in eight large aeronautical laboratories, situated at Langley Field, Va. These laboratories
are the largest and best equipped of
their kind in the world.
Headquarters in Washington

The headquarters of the Committee is in Washington, where offices
are maintained in the Navy Building. Congress has created a budget
of $520,000 to be used in areonautics, and Dr. Ames will control and
direct all expenditures of the Committee.
It was also announced that the
Dean will make a trip to Europe this
summer, leaving immediately upon
the return of President Goodnow,
who sailed for England Saturday.
While not going primarily on government business, Dr. Ames will

The resignation of Norman Chase Keyes as graduate manager
of athletics is cause for comment. We cannot help but welcome
Mr.
the action, because we feel that whatever anyone's opinion of

the treasurer's office.
Rumor has it that no one will be appointed to fill the position
next year, assuming of course, the foregone conclusion of the acceptance of the resignation by the Athletic Council. The making
of schedules can easily be carried out by undergraduate managers
with the advice of the coaches. The financial details of the athletic association could readily be handled by the treasurer of. the

Athletic publicity can be arranged by the Director of Athletics.
All of the duties that have fallen to the graduate manager can,
as has been shown, be subdivided among other individuals, allowing the salary of the graduate manager to be allocated to the purchasing of additional athletic equipment. We believe that everyone concerned will benefit by Mr. Keyes' resignation.

TH E APPOINTMENT OF DR. MILES
The appointment of Dr. L. Wardlaw Miles to the English
faculty will be viewed with a good deal of satisfaction by those
who know Dr. Miles either personally or through his writings
and lectures. He seems to be a man who combines a thorough
knowledge and ardent love of his subject with a sympathetic
understanding of those whom he is teaching. His work at the Gilman Country School was of the highest order and has marked him
as being peculiarly fitted for the position he will fill at this University next year.

WELCOME, NAVY
If one can be welcomed with the wish that he goes home sad
and down-hearted, we welcome Navy. Hopkins-Navy lacrosse
games have been classics of the sport for the past three or fur
years, and this year promises to climax a brilliant series of contests. That we will beat Navy, the NEWS-LETTER feels is more
than a possibility: we believe that the team is equal to the task.
At any rate, we welcome the Navy most heartily.

JUST A STAGE KISS
By EVANS RODGERS
entitled to a little recreation !" Oscar
a
all,
man's
it
"Damn
growled. Oscar had been arguing with Agatha, his wife. Of
course, it was on the same, age-old subject—would she never let
him alone in his pet avocation! Amateur theatricals were not, as
she continually told him, merely a beautiful opportunity for conceited asses to strut their vanity at the unwilling expense of their
friends' time. His hobby was artistic in a way. And then too,
the other fellows had their recreations: golf, tennis, insipid bridge,
and perfectly worthless canceled stamps! By God, he'd have his!
"Oscar !" came a voice from across the hall. It was spoken
in a tone suggestive of the individual he had just sworn by, but
Oscar was determined. "What!" he bellowed back. "Come here!"
and he stuck to his
s
Oscar wilted visibly, but the door was .hut
guns. "You come here," he ventured, but it was softer enough
for her to know. Agatha decided to cry: that was much the
quickest way. Oscar was always nice to her when she cried,
although she never quite knew why—she thought it disgusting.
So she opened the door very slowly and entered martyr-like, instead of blustering in like the tigress she was.
"Oscar," she said with a timely sob, "don't you really feel
anything when you kiss that awful leading lady ?" "Don't be asinine!" Evidently Oscar was madder than usual. "I feel her lips
on mine, of course." "But, dear, I mean it doesn't mean anything
at all?"
By jacks, Agatha was pretty. And here she was crying—the
dear! He slipped his arm around her; and Agatha quickly got her
head on his chest, her eyes and mouth out of sight. "Darling," he
went on softly, pitching his voice down two tones to where Mr.
Gegotensky had told him his most seducing sounds were, "a moment before I kiss her I tear up a letter, a moment after I light a
cigarette. All three of these are merely stage business—that's all.
Each one is as important as the other two, and all three most pleasant when I do them well. (Pretty nicely said, Oscar thought,
some day he'd have to write something too.) But can't you understand?" "And it doesn't mean a thing ?" "Not a thing!" he answered, and he knew he was taking the right attitude, the professional attitude.

Well, the play was over at last. Oscar sighed a little. Now
he'd have to get down to business, he'd had his fun and now to
work. Of course, it had been fun. His friends were all very kind
after his performance, and although he would surely discount some
of the more obvious flattery, these people knew what they were
talking about all right. And he wasn't such a fool as to call himself conceited when he knew he had done a good thing. No, no,
that type was the worst of all—inferiority complexes, afraid to be
frank about their good qualities. And then he had had some quite
sensible adverse criticism too. For instance, the fellow who said
his leading lady hadn't given him all the reactions she might have,
and the one who saw immediately that the play itself had held back
so many of his most attractive little touches.
But now that was all over. Yes, yes, he'd rave to get back to
the grind now, and make up for some of those long hours of rehearsing. Besides, it would please Agatha so if he quit for a while.
Yes, he'd have to tell the Spielshoppers that he simply couldn't
keep his promise about that new play of theirs. He had told them
that as soon as this other one was over, he'd come to them, but a
man couldn't waste all his time on his recreation! The world was
too much with him for that! They had been rehearsing two weeks
without him with an understudy, but—well, let the other fellow
have a shot at a part. Sure, that was it. The Spielshoppers needed
some young blood anyway. And then, too, he was very busy, very
busy. Yes, there was the answer; he'd go right over and let them
beg all they pleased; he just wouldn't do it. And he'd come back
to Agatha immediately.
The stage manager of the Spielshoppers met him at the door
of the little theater. In a moment they were inside. "Here you
are, Oscar," he was saying proudly, "your leading lady, Miss
Keener." It didn't take Oscar a second to grasp the whole situation. The large brown eyes, the perfect little nose, the luscious
mouth, the skin as clear as crystal and as smooth as velvet.
"You know, I just couldn't wait to get over to this play of
yours!" Oscar announced confidentially. "Damn glad that other
thing is over---it was such a farce! How have you managed with
the understudy? Pretty bad, eh? . . . No? What? Oh!.
Well, let's get started by all means!"
No, no, Agatha, not a thing, not a thing!

Colby became coeducational. The
College was truly a pioneer in the

Blood and something akin to thunder, heightened by bold
stage settings of red and black, provided novel entertainment at
the Playshop Theater Monday night in the forni of a fiery Spanish
melodrama.
The play is "The Great Galeoto," by Jose Echagaray, considered the best work of the playwright. It represents another addition to the list of national dramas presented by the Hopkins little
theater group this season.
Repeated curtain calls at the end of each act and almost unanimous applause during the progress of the play gave evidence of
the sympathetic reception accorded the efforts of the Playshoppers
by the most demonstrative audience of the year. •
It was the spirit and ability of the principals in the cast that
carried off successfully what was undoubtedly a very difficult and,
at times, bloody task. For the play itself is of that highly emotional type which fairly boils with the struggle of the fiercer passions and which employs diction that is sometimes too rhetorical
to be convincing. It takes good acting, in this cynical age, to keep
such a play from being laughed at.
The play was much improved, in the modern sense, according to the Play-shop management, by judicious cutting and revising of long soliloquies and asides, "naturalizing the florid artificial
diction and subduing to some slight extent the interpretation."
Jealousy, inflamed by false gossip, is the driving force of the
drama. Don Julian, a wealthy elderly Spanish gentleman, ot upright character, is happily married to a pretty young girl of twenty,
who loves him deeply. Living with them is an impulsive young
man whom Don Julian has befriended. People begin to talk maliciously of the really blameless relations between the two young
people. This gossip, broadcast by chronic scandal-mongers, among
whom is Don Julian's brother, comes finally to the ears of the husband and the insidious poison, working in him, results in bloodshed
and tragedy.
Elise Cohen, as Julian's wife carries off this very exacting
role without any awkwardness at all. Although she is not quite
equal to several of the boiling points of emotion in the play,
she displays throughout a grace and poise and variety of expression that at once attract and hold attention.
Evans Rodgers, of Barnstormers fame, in the part of the
fiery young Spaniard, has appearance against him. He has to
act against the handicap of not looking like a poet-lover-swordsman of the romantic Ramon Navarro type which the part seems
to call for. This, of course, is purely a matter of nationality or
make-up, for Rodgers certainly gets all the necessary steam behind.
the role and he really acts—there are no mistaking the particular
shades of emotion he wants to get across.
R. K.

Private Rites and Banquet Held
Last Night
Eight initiates received the laurel
leaf of Omicron Delta Kappa at
yesterday's assembly. A faculty
member, a graduate student and six
members of the undergraduate
school were honored by the society
at the public initiation. Following
a banquet last night, private rites
were performed at the Alumni Memorial Dormitory.
